facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 134 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 5, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated March 5, 1963 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 5, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1963. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants. K. Chakravarti and P. K. Bose, for the respondent. January 7, 1964.

facts.text: Six appellants convicted by Assistant Sessions Judge, Birbhum under s. 304 Part II read with s. 34 IPC and sentenced to six years rigorous imprisonment each.

anchor.surface_text: The six appellants who have appealed to this Court by special leave were companyvicted by the Assistant Sessions Judge, Birbhum under s. 304 Part II read with s. 34 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to six years rigorous imprisonment each. Their appeal to the High Court was summarily dismissed.

facts.text: Appeal to High Court summarily dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Their appeal to the High Court was summarily dismissed. When the appellants applied for a certificate in the High Court they made it plain that the only point which was required to be companysidered by this Court was whether s. 34 companyld be read in companyjunction with Part 11 of s. 304, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court rejected certificate for appeal to Supreme Court citing Ibra Akanda v. Emperor.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the application for the certificate pointing out that the companytroversy had been settled by a Full Bench decision of the High Court reported in Ibra Akanda v. Emperor 1 . The learned Judges were of the opinion that the point was number of sufficient importance for permitting the appellants to take an appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Incident occurred on morning of March 13, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: For the companysideration of the point of law which has been debated before us, we may state only such facts as will bring out the companytroversy. One Abdul Sheikh in the companypany of his son, Adut, aged 13, went to his field in village Noapara to uproot linseed plants. This was on the morning of March 13, 1962.

facts.text: Abdul Sheikh in company of son Adut aged 13 went to his field in village Noapara to uproot linseed plants.

anchor.surface_text: One Abdul Sheikh in the companypany of his son, Adut, aged 13, went to his field in village Noapara to uproot linseed plants. This was on the morning of March 13, 1962. While he was, so employed, two of the appellants, Afrahim and Jesed, appeared on the scene, and Afrahim asked Jesed to catch hold of Abdul Sheikh.

facts.text: Afrahim and Jesed appeared, Afrahim asked Jesed to catch Abdul Sheikh.

anchor.surface_text: While he was, so employed, two of the appellants, Afrahim and Jesed, appeared on the scene, and Afrahim asked Jesed to catch hold of Abdul Sheikh. Abdul Sheikh took to his heels and was chased by these two appel- lants, who overtook him and threw him down on the ground Immediately thereafter, there appeared on the scene the re- maining appellants.

facts.text: Abdul Sheikh chased by Afrahim and Jesed, overtaken and thrown down.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Sheikh took to his heels and was chased by these two appel- lants, who overtook him and threw him down on the ground Immediately thereafter, there appeared on the scene the re- maining appellants. Jarahim was armed with a ballam and he started to hit Abdul Sheikh on his legs with the ballam.

facts.text: Jarahim armed with ballam hit Abdul Sheikh on legs.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter, there appeared on the scene the re- maining appellants. Jarahim was armed with a ballam and he started to hit Abdul Sheikh on his legs with the ballam. The appellant, Manu, arrived with a sabal  crowbar , and began to strike Abdul Sheikh and the appellant, Mesher. began to strike Abdul Sheikh with a lathi.

facts.text: Manu arrived with sabal crowbar and struck Abdul Sheikh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Manu, arrived with a sabal  crowbar , and began to strike Abdul Sheikh and the appellant, Mesher. began to strike Abdul Sheikh with a lathi. All this, while, the sixth appellant, Makid, held Abdul Sheikh by the legs and Afrahim and Jesed held him down by his head and shoulders.

facts.text: Mesher struck Abdul Sheikh with lathi.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant, Mesher. began to strike Abdul Sheikh with a lathi. All this, while, the sixth appellant, Makid, held Abdul Sheikh by the legs and Afrahim and Jesed held him down by his head and shoulders. The incident was witnessed by Adut and two, others,

facts.text: Makid held Abdul Sheikh by the legs; Afrahim and Jesed held head and shoulders.

anchor.surface_text: All this, while, the sixth appellant, Makid, held Abdul Sheikh by the legs and Afrahim and Jesed held him down by his head and shoulders. The incident was witnessed by Adut and two, others, and it is on the testimony of Adut and these two I.L.R.  1944  2 Cal. 405. other witnesses,

facts.text: Incident witnessed by Adut and two others.

anchor.surface_text: The incident was witnessed by Adut and two, others, and it is on the testimony of Adut and these two I.L.R.  1944  2 Cal. 405. other witnesses, to whom reference is unnecessary, that the learned Assistant Sessions Judge, Birbhum, came to the company- clusion that the offence was companymitted in the manner described above.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge Birbhum concluded offence committed as described based on Adut and two witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: to whom reference is unnecessary, that the learned Assistant Sessions Judge, Birbhum, came to the company- clusion that the offence was companymitted in the manner described above. Abdul Sheikh was seriously injured both his legs below the knee were fractured and one arm above the wrist was also fractured.

facts.text: Abdul Sheikh seriously injured: both legs below knee fractured, one arm above wrist fractured, incised wounds, bruises.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Sheikh was seriously injured both his legs below the knee were fractured and one arm above the wrist was also fractured. He had also some incised wounds and some bruises. He was examined by one Dr. Bashiruddin, who gave him first aid.

facts.text: Abdul Sheikh examined by Dr. Bashiruddin who gave first aid; Abdul named all six appellants.

anchor.surface_text: He was examined by one Dr. Bashiruddin, who gave him first aid. Dr. Bashiruddin stated on oath that Abdul Sheikh narrated to him the incident and named all the six appellants. Later, Abdul Sheikh was removed to Nalhati Health Centre,

facts.text: Abdul Sheikh removed to Nalhati Health Centre, succumbed to injuries before dying declaration recorded.

anchor.surface_text: Later, Abdul Sheikh was removed to Nalhati Health Centre, and while arrangements were being made for recording his dying declaration, he succumbed to his injuries. He had, however, made dying declarations to some of the prosecution witnesses

facts.text: Abdul Sheikh made dying declarations to prosecution witnesses naming six appellants.

anchor.surface_text: he succumbed to his injuries. He had, however, made dying declarations to some of the prosecution witnesses and they have deposed to the fact that he had named the six appellants as his assailants. In this appeal, we did number allow Dr. D. N. Mukherjee, companynsel for the appellants, to argue on facts.

facts.text: Supreme Court assumed incident took place as narrated by witnesses, did not allow argument on facts.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, we did number allow Dr. D. N. Mukherjee, companynsel for the appellants, to argue on facts. We assumed that the incident took place as narrated by the witnesses. Mr. Mukherjee companytends that the companyviction of the appellants under s. 304, Part 11 is illegal,

facts.text: Two parties with enmity between appellants and Abdul Sheikh.

facts.text: Supreme Court found prior concert and common intention among six appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Here, in our opinion, that requirement was companypletely satisfied, because the six accused companyld number but by a prior companycert have appeared simultaneously at the scene, and chased and overthrown the victim, held him down and beaten him. The facts disclosed in the evidence clearly establish a prior companycert amongst the six appellants.

arguments.claim: Conviction under s. 304 Part II read with s. 34 IPC is illegal because s. 34 cannot be applied as Part II of s. 304 concerns knowledge and excludes intention

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mukherjee contends that the conviction of the appellants under s. 304, Part 11 is illegal, because according to him, s. 34 cannot be called in aid, as the second part of s. 304 concerns itself with knowledge and absolutely excludes intention as the ingredient of the offence.

arguments.claim: s. 34 applies to series of acts as per s. 33 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code reads as follows When a criminal act is done by several persons, in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.

arguments.claim: Criminal act under s. 34 means unity of criminal behaviour resulting in punishable offence

anchor.surface_text: In other words, as was stated by the Judicial Committee, in Barendra Kumar Ghoshs case a criminal act means. that unity of criminal behaviour, which results in something, for which an individual would be punishable

holdings.text: Section 34... has regard not to the offence as a whole, but to the criminal act, that is to say, the totality of the series of acts which result in the offence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Per s.33 'act' includes series; per Barendra Kumar Ghosh, unity of criminal behaviour.
